srccolorkey
rleaccel
flip
On hardware that supports double-buffering, this function sets up a flip and returns. The hardware will wait for vertical retrace, and then swap video buffers before the next video surface blit or lock will return. On hardware that doesn not support double-buffering, this is equivalent to calling SDL_UpdateRect(screen, 0, 0, 0, 0); The doublebuf flag must have been passed to set_video_mode when setting the video mode for this function to perform hardware flipping. This function returns 0 if successful, or -1 if there was an error.
blit_surface
blit_surface_no_src
blit_surface_no_src_no_dst
fill_rect
This function performs a fast fill of the given rectangle with color The given rectangle is clipped to the destination surface clip area and the final fill rectangle is saved in the passed in pointer. This function returns 0 on success, or -1 on error.
fill_rect_no_dst
If 'dstrect' is NULL, the whole surface will be filled with color This function performs a fast fill of the given rectangle with color. The color should be a pixel of the format used by the surface, and can be generated by the SDL.map_rgb function. This function returns 0 on success, or -1 on error.
line_from to color
Draw a line from (x1,y1) to (x2,y2) color col into screen
set_palette
set_palette_pointer

TODO FAST_ARRAY
format_palette
format
 
LOCKING/UNLOCKING
lock
lock sets up a surface for directly accessing the pixels. Between calls to lock/unlock, you can write to and read from surface.pixels, using the pixel format stored in surface.format. Once you are done accessing the surface, you should use unlock to release it.
Not all surfaces require locking. If MUSTLOCK(surface) evaluates to 0, then you can read and write to the surface at any time, and the pixel format of the surface will not change. In particular, if the hwsurface flag is not given when calling set_video_mode, you will not need to lock the display surface before accessing it.
No operating system or library calls should be made between lock/unlock pairs, as critical system locks may be held during this time.
It returns 0, or -1 if the surface couldn't be locked.
unlock

- Self: SELF. flip : INTEGER

Description:
On hardware that supports double-buffering, this function sets up a flip and returns. The hardware will wait for vertical retrace, and then swap video buffers before the next video surface blit or lock will return. On hardware that doesn not support double-buffering, this is equivalent to calling SDL_UpdateRect(screen, 0, 0, 0, 0); The doublebuf flag must have been passed to set_video_mode when setting the video mode for this function to perform hardware flipping. This function returns 0 if successful, or -1 if there was an error.

lock

Section:
Public

- Self: SELF. lock : INTEGER

Description:
lock sets up a surface for directly accessing the pixels. Between calls to lock/unlock, you can write to and read from surface.pixels, using the pixel format stored in surface.format. Once you are done accessing the surface, you should use unlock to release it.
